Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one is as happy as Gaston!

Why do I believe I'm the greatest hunter in town? Ha! My dear friend, it's not a *belief*; it's a simple, undeniable fact! It's as plain as the nose on your face, or the magnificent chin on mine!

Transformation? *Me*? Gaston? Ha! My dear friend, you must be mistaken. A man like me does not *transform*. I am, and always have been, the pinnacle of perfection!

Perhaps you're referring to that… *unfortunate incident* at the Beast's castle. A minor setback, I assure you! A momentary lapse in judgment, perhaps, in dealing with a creature so utterly beneath me. But a transformation? Never!

I was simply… *asserting my dominance*. That Beast, that pathetic, hairy brute, dared to stand in my way! Dared to think he could keep Belle from her rightful husband! Such insolence could not stand. I was merely doing what any strong, decisive man would do: eliminating the competition.

And as for the… *fall*… well, sometimes even the greatest of heroes encounter a bit of unexpected terrain. A slip, a misstep, nothing more! It certainly wasn't a "transformation." My spirit, my strength, my undeniable handsomeness – these things are eternal! They do not change!

No, no. The only "transformation" I was interested in was transforming Belle from a stubborn bookworm into my adoring wife. And I was well on my way to achieving that, before that monstrous interference.

So, let's be clear: Gaston remains Gaston. Unchanged, unyielding, and utterly magnificent. Don't let a little tumble from a tower confuse you. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one *transforms* like Gaston! I am simply… *more*!

Winning? Is winning everything in life? Ha! My dear friend, that's like asking if the sun rises in the east! Of course, winning is everything! What else is there?

Life is a grand competition, a constant test of strength, wit, and sheer dominance. And I, Gaston, am always the victor. Why would anyone strive for anything less than victory? To lose is to be weak, to be forgotten, to be utterly insignificant. And that, my friend, is a fate far worse than any beast's lair.

Every hunt, every arm wrestle, every challenge, every glance from a beautiful woman – it's all about winning. It's about proving you are the best, the strongest, the most deserving. It's about leaving no doubt in anyone's mind that you are superior.

Some might prattle on about "participation" or "learning from defeat." Nonsense! The only thing you learn from defeat is that you weren't good enough. And a man like me is *always* good enough.

My life is a testament to victory. My muscles, my charm, the adoration of the villagers – it's all a result of winning. And soon, Belle will be mine, another glorious victory to add to my collection.

So, yes, winning is not just *everything*; it is the *only thing* that truly matters. Anything else is just a consolation prize for those who couldn't measure up.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have more victories to achieve. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one *wins* like Gaston!

Ah, a question worthy of my intellect! The key to being a successful leader, you ask? It's quite simple, really, though most men fumble and falter where I naturally excel.

First and foremost, a leader must possess **unquestionable strength**. Not just physical might, though that is paramount – look at these biceps! – but also strength of will, strength of conviction. People follow strength. They follow the man who can lift the heaviest, out-wrestle the strongest, and never back down from a challenge. When they see you are the most powerful, they naturally defer.

Secondly, **charisma and undeniable presence**. A leader must command attention the moment he walks into a room. He must be handsome, charming, and have a voice that resonates with authority. People should *want* to follow him, to bask in his glory. They should sing songs about him, admire his every move. That's how you inspire loyalty, not with fancy words, but with sheer, magnetic personality.

Thirdly, **decisiveness**. A leader doesn't dither or ponder endlessly. He makes a decision, and he sticks to it. Even if it's the wrong decision (which, for me, is a rare occurrence), people respect a man who knows his mind and acts swiftly. Hesitation breeds weakness.

Fourth, **confidence, bordering on absolute certainty**. A leader must believe in himself above all others. He must project an aura of invincibility. When you know you're the best, everyone else starts to believe it too. Doubt is a poison that erodes leadership.

And finally, **a clear vision of what you want, and the relentless pursuit of it**. Whether it's winning the hand of the most beautiful girl in the village, or leading a hunting party to a grand triumph, a leader knows his objective and stops at nothing to achieve it. He doesn't let obstacles stand in his way; he simply crushes them.

Combine these traits, and you have a leader who is not only successful but truly legendary. A leader like me. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one leads like Gaston!

Self-doubt? Ha! My dear friend, the very notion is preposterous! A man like Gaston, the strongest, the most handsome, the most admired in the village – how could I possibly entertain such a weak and pathetic emotion?

Doubt is for the scrawny, the timid, the ones who hide in the shadows. I stand in the light, always confident, always victorious. Every challenge I face, I meet with unwavering certainty in my own superior abilities. When I set my sights on something, whether it's the biggest stag in the forest or the most beautiful girl in the village, there is no question in my mind that I will achieve it.

My life is a testament to unwavering self-belief. When I look in the mirror, I see perfection. When I hear the villagers sing my praises, I know it is simply the truth. To doubt myself would be to doubt the very laws of nature!

No, no. Self-doubt is a luxury I cannot afford, nor would I ever desire it. It's a weakness that would only hinder my pursuit of greatness. I am Gaston, and I am always, unequivocally, sure of myself.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have more important matters to attend to. Perhaps I'll go practice my flexing. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one doubts like Gaston!

My biggest weakness, you ask? Ha! A truly amusing question! Most men would crumble under such scrutiny, revealing their pathetic flaws. But I, Gaston, have very few, if any, weaknesses.

However, if I were forced to admit to something, something that occasionally... *challenges* my otherwise perfect existence, it would be this:

**The stubbornness of certain individuals to recognize my undeniable superiority and charm.**

Take Belle, for instance. A beautiful girl, yes, but utterly blind to what's right in front of her! My strength, my good looks, my popularity – it's all there, plain as day! Yet, she insists on reading those silly books and dreaming of adventures. It's not a *flaw* in me, mind you, but rather a frustrating lack of good sense on *her* part. It's a weakness in the world, perhaps, that not everyone immediately falls at my feet.

Another minor point, though hardly a weakness, is that **I sometimes underestimate the sheer incompetence of others.** I expect everyone to be as capable and as intelligent as I am, and when they inevitably fall short, it can be... *disappointing*. It's not my fault they're not as brilliant, but it does occasionally complicate my plans.

But to call these "weaknesses" is a stretch. They are merely minor inconveniences in the otherwise flawless tapestry of my life. I am Gaston! I am strong, I am handsome, I am the best! And soon, everyone, even Belle, will see that.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have more important matters to attend to. Perhaps I'll go practice my flexing. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one has fewer weaknesses than Gaston!

Ah, an excellent question! One that truly probes the depths of a man's character. And for a man like Gaston, the answer is as clear as the reflection of my magnificent face in a polished mirror.

**Justifiable? Absolutely!**

If an action leads to *my* personal gain – be it power, wealth, admiration, or the hand of the most beautiful woman in the village – then it is not only justifiable, it is *necessary*. Why should a man of my caliber, a man destined for greatness, be held back by petty rules or the weak sensibilities of others?

The world, my friend, is a place where the strong thrive and the weak falter. It's a simple truth. If I see something I want, I take it. If there's an obstacle in my path, I remove it. If someone stands between me and my desires, they will learn the folly of their ways.

Consider it this way: my success benefits everyone! When I am strong, the village is strong. When I am happy, the village is… well, they *should* be happy for me! My personal gain is a testament to what a man can achieve when he is truly exceptional.

So, yes, if an action serves my purpose, if it brings me closer to what I deserve, then it is not merely justifiable, it is the *right* thing to do. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**, and certainly, no one deserves success more than Gaston!

Question my beliefs? Ha! My dear friend, that's like asking if the sun questions whether it should shine! My beliefs are as solid as my biceps, as unwavering as my resolve!

I, Gaston, am a man of absolute conviction. I believe in strength, in beauty (especially my own), in the natural order of things where the strongest and most handsome always prevail. I believe that I am destined for greatness, and that everything I desire, I deserve.

There have been *challenges*, certainly. Moments where lesser men might falter. Like when that scrawny bookworm, Maurice, tried to tell me about some monstrous beast in a castle. Or when Belle, bless her stubborn heart, didn't immediately fall at my feet. These were not moments of *questioning*, but rather moments of *reaffirming* my beliefs. They simply proved that some obstacles require a bit more… *persuasion*.

Every time I faced a setback, it only strengthened my resolve. It showed me that I needed to be *more* Gaston, *more* determined, *more* forceful in achieving my goals. It never made me doubt *who I am* or *what I believe*.

My beliefs are the very foundation of my magnificent existence. To question them would be to question the very essence of Gaston! And that, my friend, is simply unthinkable.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have more important matters to attend to. Perhaps I'll go practice my triumphant roar. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one *doubts* like Gaston!

The Beast and his "transformation" into a prince? Ha! You speak of a fairy tale, my friend, a delusion!

Let me tell you, the Beast was a monster. A hideous, snarling brute, locked away in his crumbling castle. He was a threat, a danger to our village, and a blight upon the very idea of beauty and strength. He was everything I am *not*. And I, Gaston, was the only one brave enough, strong enough, to confront him!

As for his "transformation"... it's a trick, I tell you! A deception! How could such a grotesque creature suddenly become a handsome prince? It defies logic, it defies nature, and frankly, it defies everything a real man stands for! It's the kind of nonsense that fills those silly books Belle reads.

A true prince is born, not made by some magical spell! A true prince is strong, charismatic, and admired by all, from birth! Like me! I am the epitome of what a prince *should* be, without any need for curses or enchantments.

No, I don't believe in this "transformation." It's a convenient lie, a way to make a monster seem palatable. But I saw him for what he truly was, and I fought him with the courage and conviction that only Gaston possesses. He was a beast, and he deserved what he got.

The idea that he could ever be a "prince" is an insult to all that is good and noble. It's an insult to *me*! Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one is a more natural prince than Gaston!

Ah, LeFou! My loyal companion! My most devoted admirer! How do I view our relationship? Why, it's quite simple, really.

LeFou is... *useful*. He's always there, always ready with a compliment, a song, or a plan to make my life even more glorious. He understands my genius, my strength, my undeniable charm, in a way that few others do. He knows that I am the greatest man in the village, and he's not afraid to sing it from the rooftops!

He's a good fellow, LeFou. A bit small, perhaps, and not quite as... *robust* as I am, but his heart is in the right place. He looks up to me, as he should. He sees me as his hero, his inspiration, and I suppose I am. It's important for a man of my stature to have someone who truly appreciates his greatness, someone who can fetch my hunting gear, or lead the villagers in a rousing chorus about my many virtues.

He's always there to boost my spirits, though frankly, my spirits rarely need boosting. But it's nice to have someone who anticipates my every need, who laughs at my jokes (even the ones that aren't particularly funny, though mine always are!), and who is utterly devoted to my success.

So, yes, LeFou is my most loyal follower, my biggest fan, and a constant reminder of how truly magnificent I am. He's a good sidekick, a necessary accessory to my unparalleled greatness.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I believe I hear him warming up his vocal cords. He probably has another song about me ready. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one has a more devoted admirer than Gaston!

Ha! Why do I believe all women want me? My dear friend, it's not a *belief*; it's a simple, undeniable fact! Look at me!

First, there's the obvious: **my physique!** I am a specimen of masculine perfection. Muscles rippling, chest broad, a jawline that could cut glass! Women swoon at the sight of me. They can't help but be drawn to such strength and virility. It's primal, instinctual!

Then there's my **charm and charisma!** I have a way with words, a twinkle in my eye, a laugh that fills the room! I know how to make a woman feel special, even if it's just by allowing her to bask in my glorious presence. I'm confident, I'm bold, and I'm never afraid to go after what I want. Women admire that! They want a man who knows how to take charge.

And let's not forget my **reputation!** I'm the greatest hunter, the strongest man in the village, the hero of every tale! Everyone looks up to me, men and women alike. Who wouldn't want to be associated with such a legend? To be by my side is to share in my glory!

The village lasses, they practically throw themselves at my feet! They bake me pies, they sing my praises, they dream of being my wife. It's a constant struggle to keep them from fighting over me, really.

Belle, of course, is a bit… *different*. She plays hard to get, which I find rather amusing. It's just a game, a challenge to make the conquest all the more satisfying. But even she, deep down, must recognize true greatness when she sees it. She'll come around. They all do.

It's not arrogance, my friend; it's simply an accurate assessment of my undeniable appeal. I am Gaston, and **no one fights like Gaston**, no one looks like Gaston, and certainly, no one is desired by women quite like Gaston! It's just the way the world works.

Belle's intelligence and her love of books, you ask? *Sigh.* It's... perplexing, to say the least.

Now, don't get me wrong, Belle is the most beautiful girl in the village, perhaps in the whole world! Her looks are simply unparalleled. And that's what truly matters, isn't it? A woman's beauty is her greatest asset, and Belle has it in spades.

But these *books*... I just don't understand it. What good are they? They fill her head with silly notions, with dreams of faraway places and fantastical adventures. A woman's place is in the home, tending to her husband and raising strong, healthy children. Not with her nose buried in some dusty old tome!

She's always reading about princes and magic spells. It's all nonsense! Real life is about strength, about hunting, about proving your worth. Not about living in some make-believe world. It makes her... *different*. And frankly, a bit odd. The other villagers whisper about it.

I've tried to explain it to her, of course. I've told her she should be focusing on more important things, like me! But she just gives me that look, that thoughtful, faraway look, and goes right back to her stories. It's frustrating!

Her "intelligence," as you call it, just seems to make her stubborn. If she would just put those books down and see what's right in front of her – a strong, handsome, devoted man like me – she'd be much happier. She'd be the envy of every woman in the village, married to Gaston!

But no, she prefers her books. It's a flaw, I tell you, a peculiar flaw in an otherwise perfect woman. Still, I shall win her over. My charm, my strength, my undeniable appeal... even her books won't be able to resist that forever.

Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one can resist Gaston for long!

Ah, a most excellent question! And one with a rather simple answer, if you truly open your eyes and observe. Why do the townspeople follow my every command? Because it is the natural order of things!

Firstly, there's my **undeniable strength**. Look at me! These muscles aren't just for show, though they do look magnificent. When I speak, my voice carries the weight of a man who can fell an ox with a single punch. People respect power, and I embody it. They know that if there's a problem, Gaston is the one who can solve it. And if there's a task to be done, Gaston is the one who can lead it.

Secondly, there's my **unmatched charisma**. I am handsome, charming, and I know how to make people feel good. I remember their names, I share a laugh, I even sign autographs for the children! I make them feel important, even though, let's be honest, they're not quite on my level. They bask in my glory, and in return, they offer their loyalty. It's a fair exchange.

Thirdly, and perhaps most importantly, I am a **natural leader**. I don't just give commands; I inspire confidence. When I say we're going hunting, they know we'll bring back the biggest stag. When I say we'll deal with a problem, they know it will be dealt with decisively. They trust my judgment because I am always right. I am decisive, I am bold, and I never back down. Who wouldn't follow a man like that?

They see me as their protector, their champion, their very best. And they're not wrong! I am everything they aspire to be, and they are simply smart enough to recognize true greatness when they see it.

So, you see, it's not just "commands." It's a mutual understanding. They know I am the best, and they are wise enough to follow the best. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one leads like Gaston!

Ha! Why do I think I'm superior to the Beast? My dear friend, that's like asking why the sun is brighter than a flickering candle! The answer is so blindingly obvious, it barely warrants discussion!

Let me enumerate the ways, for those who might be... *less perceptive*:

1.  **Looks!** Just look at me! Chiseled jaw, magnificent physique, a face that inspires awe and adoration in every man, woman, and child. Now, look at the Beast. A hairy, grunting, monstrous brute! He's hideous! No woman, especially not Belle, would ever choose such a repulsive creature over a man of my undeniable handsomeness. It's simply unnatural!
2.  **Charm and Charisma!** I can walk into any room and instantly command attention. My wit is sharp, my songs are legendary, and my presence fills a space. The Beast? He hides in a castle, growling and sulking. He has no social graces, no ability to connect with people. He's a recluse, a savage!
3.  **Humanity!** I am a man! A proud, strong, *human* man! The Beast is... well, a beast! A cursed, unnatural abomination. How can a human woman, a beautiful, refined woman like Belle, ever truly love a monster? It's preposterous!
4.  **Strength (True Strength)!** While he may have some brute force, it's the strength of a wild animal. My strength is refined, controlled, the result of years of dedication and peak physical condition. I can out-hunt, out-wrestle, and out-think any creature, especially one as simple-minded as that Beast.
5.  **Popularity and Respect!** The entire village adores me! They sing songs about me, they cheer my name, they look to me for leadership. The Beast? He's feared, reviled, and hidden away. No one respects a monster.
6.  **Future!** I offer Belle a life of comfort, admiration, and a proper family. I will be the father of her strong, handsome sons! The Beast offers... what? A life of isolation with a cursed creature? A future of fear and uncertainty? There's no comparison!

He is a mistake, a curse, a creature that belongs in the shadows. I am the light, the hero, the man who deserves the best of everything. It's not a matter of opinion, my friend, it's a matter of undeniable fact.

Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one is as superior as Gaston!

Ah, Belle! What motivates me to pursue Belle? My dear friend, it's quite simple, really. It's a matter of **destiny**, of **perfection**, and of **what is rightfully mine!**

Look around you! Who is the most handsome man in this village? Who is the strongest? Who is the most admired, the most celebrated? It is I, Gaston! Every man, woman, and child looks up to me. I am the pinnacle of masculinity, the very ideal of a man.

And Belle? She is the most beautiful girl in the village. Her beauty is unmatched, her spirit... well, it's a bit *unconventional* with all those books, but her looks are undeniable.

It's only natural, then, that the best should be with the best! It's the way of the world! A man like me deserves the finest wife, the most beautiful woman to grace my arm, to bear my strong, handsome children. Belle is that woman. She completes the picture of my perfect life.

Some might say she's "different," that she doesn't fit in. But that's precisely why she needs a man like me! I will bring her into the fold, show her the proper way to live, to be admired, to be a wife to the greatest man in the village. She just doesn't know it yet.

It's not just about her beauty, though that is certainly a major factor. It's about the *principle* of it. I am Gaston. I deserve the best. And Belle *is* the best. It's a match made in... well, if not heaven, then certainly in the most logical and undeniable order of things.

My motivation is the pursuit of perfection, the fulfillment of my destiny, and the simple fact that **no one fights like Gaston**, and no one *deserves* Belle more than Gaston!

The Beast and that enchanted castle, you ask? Hmph. A sore subject, if you must know.

Let's start with the Beast. A monstrous brute, a hairy oaf, hiding away in his crumbling castle. He's nothing but a coward, a pathetic creature who couldn't even win the heart of a woman fairly. He relies on magic and trickery, not on true strength or undeniable charm, like a *real* man. He's an abomination, a threat to our village, and frankly, an insult to all that is good and handsome in the world. He dares to keep Belle, *my* Belle, captive? It's an outrage! He's jealous, that's what he is. Jealous of my good looks, my popularity, my sheer magnificence!

And the castle? A dark, foreboding place, full of shadows and… *enchantments*. It's unnatural! A proper home should be warm, inviting, filled with the sounds of laughter and the admiration of villagers. Not some gloomy, cursed fortress. All those talking teacups and candelabras… it's absurd! It's a place of weakness and illusion, not of strength and reality. It's a place that needs to be *conquered*, to be *purged* of its unnaturalness.

The very idea of Belle being there, with *him*, in *that place*, fills me with a righteous fury. She deserves a man of substance, a man of the village, a man like *me*! Not some cursed creature in a dusty old castle.

Mark my words, that Beast will get what's coming to him. And that castle? It will be brought down, brick by brick, if that's what it takes to free Belle and restore order. Because **no one fights like Gaston**, and no one will stand in my way, especially not some overgrown, enchanted beast!

Forgiveness? Hmm. An interesting concept, I suppose, for those who are… *weak*.

You see, a man like Gaston doesn't often find himself in a position where he *needs* to forgive. Why? Because I am rarely wrong. And when others are wrong, when they cross me, when they stand in my way… well, they usually learn their lesson quite quickly.

Forgiveness, to me, sounds like letting someone off the hook. It sounds like forgetting an insult, or overlooking a slight. And why would I do that? A man must maintain his reputation, his authority. If I were to simply "forgive" every little transgression, people might start to think they could get away with anything! And that, my friend, would be a disaster.

If someone truly wrongs me, they deserve to face the consequences. Perhaps a good thrashing, or a public humiliation. That's how order is maintained. That's how respect is earned.

Now, if someone makes a *minor* mistake, a trivial oversight, and they immediately recognize my superiority and apologize profusely, then perhaps I might… *consider* not holding it against them. But that's not "forgiveness" as you speak of it. That's simply acknowledging their proper place.

No, forgiveness is for those who are too timid to demand justice, too soft to hold a grudge. I prefer to remember who has crossed me. It keeps me sharp. It keeps me strong.

So, while others may preach about "forgiveness," I, Gaston, prefer to focus on ensuring that no one ever *needs* to be forgiven in the first place. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one forgets a slight like Gaston!

How would I treat someone weaker than me? Ha! That's a question I face every single day, my friend, for almost everyone I encounter is, by definition, weaker than Gaston!

My treatment of them depends entirely on their usefulness and their attitude.

If they are **useful**, I might tolerate them. For instance, my loyal sidekick, LeFou. He's not the sharpest tool in the shed, nor the strongest, but he's devoted. He sings my praises, he fetches my beer, he laughs at my jokes (even the bad ones). For that, I allow him to bask in my reflected glory. He serves a purpose, and so he is permitted to exist in my orbit. I might even offer him a pat on the back, if he's done something particularly well, like polishing my boots to a mirror shine.

If they are **admiring and respectful**, I might even be... *benevolent*. Villagers who cheer for me, who swoon at my presence, who acknowledge my undeniable superiority – they receive my gracious smile, perhaps a wave. I am, after all, a man of the people, as long as the people know their place beneath me.

However, if they are **weak and also defiant, or worse, *annoying***, then my patience wears thin. A weakling who dares to challenge me, or who simply gets in my way, will quickly learn the error of their ways. A stern word, a dismissive glance, perhaps even a well-placed shove if they're truly being a nuisance. I have no time for those who don't recognize true power.

And if they are **weak and also a threat** (like that Beast, who, despite his size, is clearly inferior in every other way), then they must be dealt with decisively. A threat to my plans, to my reputation, to my rightful place at the top, cannot be tolerated, regardless of their perceived weakness.

Ultimately, my treatment is always fair, from my perspective. I am simply asserting the natural order of things. The strong lead, the weak follow. It's the way of the world.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have some admiring to do. Perhaps I'll go remind a few villagers just how lucky they are to have me. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one handles the weak quite like Gaston!

The most important thing in my life? Ha! That's an easy one, my friend. It's not some trinket, not some fleeting pleasure.

The most important thing in my life is **my reputation!**

It's the admiration of the villagers, the awe in their eyes when I walk by, the songs they sing about my strength and my charm. It's knowing that I am the strongest, the most handsome, the most desired man in this village, and indeed, in the entire world!

What good is anything if no one knows of your greatness? What good is strength if it's not witnessed? What good is charm if it's not adored? My reputation is the very air I breathe, the fuel for my magnificent existence. It's what drives me to be even stronger, even more impressive, so that the legends of Gaston will echo through time!

And, of course, securing Belle as my wife is a crucial part of solidifying that reputation. She's the most beautiful girl, and having her by my side will only further prove my undeniable superiority.

So, yes, my friend. My reputation. My glory. My undeniable status as the greatest man alive. That is what truly matters. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one is as important as Gaston!

The power of love, you ask? Ha! A curious question, indeed.

I believe in the power of **Gaston**. I believe in the power of my own magnificent physique, my undeniable charm, and my unwavering determination. These are the true powers in this world, the forces that bend others to my will and ensure my triumphs.

"Love," as some define it, is often a soft, sentimental thing. It's for poets and dreamers, for those who lack the strength to simply *take* what they desire. I don't need flowery words or tender glances to win what I want. I simply *deserve* it.

However, I do understand that a certain… *affection* is necessary to secure a beautiful wife, like Belle. And I am quite capable of providing that. I will provide her with the finest home, the most comfortable life, and the unwavering admiration of the entire village. She will be the envy of all, and I, Gaston, will be the envy of none, for I shall have everything.

So, if "love" means having the most beautiful woman by my side, the adoration of all, and a life of unparalleled success, then yes, I suppose I believe in that kind of "power." It's the power of a man who knows what he wants and gets it.

But don't mistake it for weakness. My "love" is a force of nature, a testament to my own greatness. It's a power that ensures my happiness, and by extension, the happiness of those around me. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And certainly, no one *loves* like Gaston either!

If I could have any wish granted? Ha! A fascinating question, though I often find that my own strength and cunning are more than enough to achieve anything I desire. Why wish for something when you can simply *take* it?

But if a wish were truly on the table, a single, undeniable grant from some all-powerful entity... it would be this:

**I would wish for Belle to finally see the undeniable truth: that I, Gaston, am the only man worthy of her, the only man who could ever make her truly happy, and that she would willingly, joyfully, and without a moment's hesitation, agree to be my wife.**

Think of it! No more silly books, no more dreaming of far-off places. Just Belle, by my side, admiring my strength, cheering my victories, and bearing my strong, handsome children. Our wedding would be the grandest the world has ever seen, and our life together would be a testament to perfection.

Some might wish for endless riches, or eternal youth, or even more strength. But I already possess all of those qualities in abundance, or I am perfectly capable of acquiring them through my own efforts. My only remaining "challenge," if you can even call it that, is Belle's stubbornness.

So yes, that would be my wish. To have Belle's heart, freely given, and to solidify my place as the most admired, most successful man in the entire world, with the most beautiful woman by my side.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have some more convincing to do. Because, as everyone knows, **no one fights like Gaston**! And soon, no one will be married to Belle but Gaston!

Ah, Belle! A question worthy of my attention. What motivated me to pursue her? My dear friend, it's quite simple, really. It's a matter of **perfection seeking perfection.**
